Slightly

Key Elements of Your Situation:
‚Ä¢	Common-law relationship: 15 years
‚Ä¢	3 children
‚Ä¢	Your income: $150K
‚Ä¢	His income: $550K
‚Ä¢	You receive full child support
‚Ä¢	Equal asset division
‚Ä¢	$150K one-time spousal support payment
‚∏ª
What This Means in Context:
1. Child Support Already Helps Offset Income Disparity
If you‚Äôre receiving full Table child support (i.e., based on his $550K income and you having primary or majority parenting time), that could be $2,000‚Äì$3,000+ per month‚Äîa meaningful monthly contribution.
However, child support is for the children, not for your personal needs or long-term support. Courts don‚Äôt consider child support a substitute for spousal support, though it may reduce the amount or duration of spousal support in some cases.
‚∏ª
2. Equal Asset Division
Equal asset division means there‚Äôs no property-based compensation for career sacrifices, homemaking, or lost income opportunity. So, unless the asset division is tilted heavily in your favour (which it‚Äôs not here), that also doesn‚Äôt replace spousal support.
‚∏ª
3. Is $150,000 Fair in this Context?
The SSAG estimates showed a 10-year total spousal support range of $900,000 to $1.2 million. If you‚Äôre receiving just $150,000, even with child support and an equal split of property:
‚Ä¢	It‚Äôs still well below the lower guideline unless there‚Äôs a strong justification (e.g., you asked for a clean break).
‚Ä¢	It could potentially be seen as unfair by a judge unless you voluntarily waive support with legal advice.
‚∏ª
Bottom Line
‚Ä¢	If the $150K is truly meant to replace ongoing spousal support, it is likely inadequate under Ontario family law norms unless supported by other compensating factors (which don‚Äôt seem present here).
‚Ä¢	It may be acceptable only if:
‚Ä¢	You are choosing it in exchange for a clean break.
‚Ä¢	You‚Äôve had independent legal advice and fully understand the tradeoffs.
‚Ä¢	The child support is generous and ongoing.
‚Ä¢	You‚Äôre confident in your long-term financial security.
